author: By Barry Gewen
title: The Book That Shaped Foreign Policy for a Generation Has More to Say
description: Hans Morgenthau’s “Politics Among Nations” taught thinkers from George F. Kennan to Henry Kissinger to put national interest above idealism. America is still learning that lesson.
content: Lurching from crisis to crisis and assailed even by allies for its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, the United States has rarely seemed more absent from the international stage, or more urgently in need of defining its role in world affairs. This may be a good time, therefore, to look back at a book from another era when fundamental questions about foreign policy were being asked — and answered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Three Children Have Died in New York of Illness Linked to Virus
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said New York was working with the C.D.C. to investigate a mysterious illness linked to the coronavirus that causes life-threatening inflammation in children.
content: Three young children have died in New York of a mysterious, toxic-shock inflammation syndrome with links to the coronavirus, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: William Barr’s Perversion of Justice
description: The attorney general is turning the Justice Department into a political weapon for the president.
content: “History is written by the winners,” William Barr, the attorney general, said Thursday when asked how he thought future generations would assess his decision to drop all criminal charges against Michael Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, who had pleaded guilty twice to breaking the law. “So it largely depends on who’s writing the history.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelina Jolie
title: Angelina Jolie: A Mother’s Strength
description: This year, I’m remembering my mom’s spirit, and the power of so many women I’ve met around the world.
content: Mother’s Day is hard for anyone who has lost their mom, but this year must be particularly so because of coronavirus. So many people have lost a parent suddenly, without being by their side, able to care for them and return their love in the way they’d always imagined.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Top Health Officials to Quarantine After Being Exposed
description: Three children have died of a mysterious syndrome linked to the virus. Trump’s support among seniors slips as the pandemic becomes more political.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Sister Fights to Free Uighur Businessman Held in China After U.S. Trip
description: Ekpar Asat came to the United States for the State Department’s most prestigious program for foreign citizens. Chinese security officers detained him weeks after he returned home.
content: WASHINGTON — When Ekpar Asat saw his older sister for the last time one winter night in Manhattan, he promised her he would return to the United States in a few months with their parents to watch her graduate with a oligarch’s degree from Harvard Law School — the first ethnic Uighur to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Anxious About the Virus, Older Voters Grow More Wary of Trump
description: Surveys show the president’s standing with seniors, the group most vulnerable to the coronavirus, has fallen as he pushes to reopen the country.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Edward Wong
title: U.S. Hits Back at China With New Visa Restrictions on Journalists
description: The Trump administration is imposing 90-day limits on work visas for Chinese journalists, raising the threat of further retaliation by the Chinese government.
content: The Trump administration is imposing new restrictions on Chinese journalists working in the United States, escalating its conflict with China over the news media as the two countries battle for economic, geopolitical and messaging dominance worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: The Class Divide: Remote Learning at 2 Schools, Private and Public
description: Some private schools provide online luxury learning during the pandemic. As many public schools struggle to adjust, the nation’s educational gaps widen.
content: For Rachel Warach’s class, the 133rd morning of first grade, numbered on a poster board behind her, was similar to all of the previous mornings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York City Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
content: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: William Barr’s Perversion of Justice
description: The attorney general is turning the Justice Department into a political weapon for the president.
content: “History is written by the winners,” William Barr, the attorney general, said Thursday when asked how he thought future generations would assess his decision to drop all criminal charges against Michael Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, who had pleaded guilty twice to breaking the law. “So it largely depends on who’s writing the history.”

content: Mother’s Day is hard for anyone who has lost their mom, but this year must be particularly so because of coronavirus. So many people have lost a parent suddenly, without being by their side, able to care for them and return their love in the way they’d always imagined.

title: Sister Fights to Free Uighur Businessman Held in China After U.S. Trip
description: Ekpar Asat came to the United States for the State Department’s most prestigious program for foreign citizens. Chinese security officers detained him weeks after he returned home.
content: WASHINGTON — When Ekpar Asat saw his older sister for the last time one winter night in Manhattan, he promised her he would return to the United States in a few months with their parents to watch her graduate with a oligarch’s degree from Harvard Law School — the first ethnic Uighur to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Anxious About the Virus, Older Voters Grow More Wary of Trump
description: Surveys show the president’s standing with seniors, the group most vulnerable to the coronavirus, has fallen as he pushes to reopen the country.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]

title: U.S. Hits Back at China With New Visa Restrictions on Journalists
description: The Trump administration is imposing 90-day limits on work visas for Chinese journalists, raising the threat of further retaliation by the Chinese government.
content: The Trump administration is imposing new restrictions on Chinese journalists working in the United States, escalating its conflict with China over the news media as the two countries battle for economic, geopolitical and messaging dominance worldwide.

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: The Class Divide: Remote Learning at 2 Schools, Private and Public
description: Some private schools provide online luxury learning during the pandemic. As many public schools struggle to adjust, the nation’s educational gaps widen.
content: For Rachel Warach’s class, the 133rd morning of first grade, numbered on a poster board behind her, was similar to all of the previous mornings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: New York City Coronavirus Map and Case Count
description: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
content: A detailed map shows the extent of the coronavirus outbreak, with charts and tables of the number of cases and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mitch Smith
title: In Chicago and Los Angeles, Virus Spread Is Slower, but Persistent
description: Cook County, Ill., which includes Chicago, added more new cases than any other U.S. county on some recent days.
content: As cases of the coronavirus spiraled upward in New York City, leaders of other big cities watched with worry, searching for ways to avoid an escalation of the magnitude that might overwhelm hospitals. In Chicago, the nation’s third-largest city, fear of explosive growth — the kind that overtook New York City, Detroit and New Orleans — has faded in recent days, but the Chicago area has faced its own stubbornly high numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Yourish, K.K. Rebecca Lai, Danielle Ivory and Mitch Smith
title: One-Third of All U.S. Coronavirus Deaths Are Nursing Home Residents or Workers
description: In at least 14 states, more than half of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities for older adults, according to a New York Times database.
content: In at least 14 states, more than half of coronavirus deaths are tied to long-term care facilities for older adults, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Approves First Antigen Test for Detecting the Coronavirus
description: The test offers medical workers and health authorities an inexpensive tool for fast, mass screening.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon and Mohammed Najib
title: Israel Cracks Down on Banks Over Payments to Palestinian Inmates
description: An Israeli military order forbids banks in the occupied West Bank from processing payments that the Palestinian Authority distributes to the families of Palestinians who have spent time in Israeli jails.
content: JERUSALEM — Even as Israel is collaborating with West Bank officials to fight the coronavirus, a new Israeli military order taking effect on Saturday forbids banks in the occupied territory from processing payments that the Palestinian Authority distributes to the families of thousands of Palestinians who have spent time in Israeli jails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: As South Korea Eases Limits, Virus Cluster Prompts Seoul to Close Bars
description: With no vaccine in sight, the country is urging people to reclaim more of their daily lives, while bracing for new waves that are all but inevitable.
content: Go out, socialize and have fun, South Korea’s government told its people, declaring the start of “a new daily life with Covid-19” — while keeping a vigilant eye out for any sign of backsliding, any need for restrictions to snap back into place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Johnson and Ruth Fremson
title: How 5 Friends and a Field of Tulips Fought the Covid-19 Meltdown
description: A group of old high school friends moved home and bought a tulip farm, just as the coronavirus threatened to devastate the industry. Here’s how the power of friendship and innovation saved them.
content: MOUNT VERNON, Wash. — When the Mount Vernon High School Bulldogs faced off against their basketball rivals a generation ago, five friends from the class of 1994 were the spark plugs, game after game. Three were on the cheer squad, stoking school spirit; two were on court, scoring points.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One-Pot Vegetarian Spicy Red Beans Are #1
description: Punjabi-style beans, sheet-pan gnocchi and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Tejal Rao’s Punjabi-style red beans with cream or mozzarella (above), Samin Nosrat’s big lasagna and Melissa Clark’s rhubarb custard bars. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Back to College in the Fall?
description: Students, parents and professors express their wishes and worries. “Parents are not going to play games with the lives of their children,” one reader says.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gerstel
title: I Survived Vietnam. Will I Survive This Pandemic?
description: Chance rules. Leaders lie. Deaths become statistics. The parallels between the disease and the war are everywhere.
content: SARNANO, Italy — A very long time ago, I was one of more than two million American men and women who served their country in Vietnam. We fought; too many of us became casualties and died. We were gone from home and half forgotten, living and dying in an alternative reality.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 Films to Watch With Mom
description: Remind her that she’s the best: You can stream these shorts right here, from the safety of home.
content: Some of us may be far from family this year, but we can still celebrate Mom, wherever she is. We’ve put together a collection of our favorite short documentaries for Mother’s Day, by some of the best filmmakers around. Even if you’re not watching together, these are films to stream with family and then jump on the phone or Zoom to ask each other: Which one moved you most?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernardo Zacka
title: An Ode to the Humble Balcony
description: It is private, yet public; exposed, yet secluded. It offers company without the demands of intimacy, and we should never take it for granted again.
content: My toddler and I have a new favorite activity: craning our necks to catch a glimpse of the neighbors. Since we have been instructed to stay at home in our apartment in a triple-decker in Somerville, Mass., we have gotten quite good at it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Sharon LaFraniere, Michael D. Shear and Ben Protess
title: Whistle-Blower Exposes Infighting and Animus in Trump’s Coronavirus Response
description: The allegations suggest personal clashes influenced how the administration responded to the pandemic.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: A First Among Gerber Babies: She’s Adopted
description: Magnolia Earl, a 1-year-old from California, was selected from among more than 327,000 entrants to represent Gerber in marketing campaigns.
content: After featuring nearly a dozen tiny brand ambassadors as the face of its baby food and other early childhood products, Gerber announced on Friday it had selected the first adopted “spokesbaby” in its 92-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell and Kevin Draper
title: How Justin Gaethje Won the Interim Lightweight Title at U.F.C. 249
description: Justin Gaethje beat Tony Ferguson in the fifth round to win an interim lightweight belt at U.F.C. 249. It was the first major American sporting event since widespread shutdowns because of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Justin Gaethje and Tony Ferguson were matched to provide action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Ross and Amelia Nierenberg
title: ‘It’s Hard When You Can’t Go Anywhere’: Life Inside an Assisted Living Facility
description: We gave disposable cameras to six residents of Evergreen Gardens, a long-term-care residence in Colorado, so they could document their days during the coronavirus pandemic. These are their photographs.
content: We gave disposable cameras to six residents of Evergreen Gardens, a long-term-care residence in Colorado, so they could document their days during the coronavirus pandemic. These are their photographs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Jim Rutenberg
title: Fight Over Virus’s Death Toll Opens Grim New Front in Election Battle
description: Elements of the right have sought to bolster President Trump’s political standing by turning scientific questions into political issues.
content: The claim was tailor-made for President Trump’s most steadfast backers: Federal guidelines are coaching doctors to mark Covid-19 as the cause of death even when it is not, inflating the pandemic’s death toll.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 9, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 9, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about countries’ efforts to safely reopen their economies misstated the surname of the director of the Center for Health Security at Johns Hopkins University. He is Tom Inglesby, not Tom Inglesbury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Spaceship Earth’ and ‘Valley Girl’
description: A documentary on the sci-fi-esque Biosphere 2 experiment arrives on Hulu, and a jukebox-musical remake of the 1983 movie “Valley Girl” debuts on Amazon.
content: SPACESHIP EARTH (2020) Stream on Hulu. This documentary takes viewers inside Biosphere 2 (known as No. 2 because Biosphere 1 is the Earth), an experimental research facility that was built by a Texas oil tycoon to prove that humans could remain healthy while quarantining in a bubble. Built in Oracle, Ariz., with its own mini-rainforest, desert and ocean with a living coral reef, the idyllic bubble was meant to prepare scientists for space colonization. But in 1991, when the first eight scientists sealed themselves inside the terrarium-like habitat for the two-year experiment, things went awry. Directed by Matt Wolf (“Teenage”), this film looks at the odd and dark twists that took place in the utopian biosphere.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Churches Weigh the Risk of Reopening Their Doors
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 9, 2020.
content: “We’ve somehow maintained a real intimacy and sweetness because we leaned into the values that always held us.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon remind us of someone, if that someone happens to be a tough cookie.
content: ACROSTIC — Argh, another difficult acrostic, agreed? If you happen to be here still hoping for hints and no spoilers, remember that Sunday is a holiday and this savage puzzle pays suitably wild homage to those we celebrate. Oh, also, if you’re feeling at all fraught today and hope to avoid anything emotionally charged, you might skip the video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: Singles Have to Think Outside the Screen
description: Matchmakers are seeing higher demand for advice and coaching services now that drinks and dinner are on hold.
content: Before the coronavirus pandemic hit, Cedric DuBose of Houston was completing a nine-week online course called “Love Alchemy.” The workshop, intended to get him thinking about his relationship skills, was a prerequisite to hiring Amari Ice, a Washington-based matchmaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: No Debating Their Love
description: Sparks flew at their initial meeting, as he criticized her style of activism. They quickly realized their attraction wasn’t just about politics.
content: A disagreement about the politics of confrontation was at the heart of the first conversation that Kelly Witwicki Faddegon and Jacy Reese Anthis had when they met, at the beginning of summer in 2014.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Disquisition
description: Miriam Estrin makes her crossword debut, in collaboration with Erik Agard.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Today we have another fun themeless grid from Erik Agard and a new sidekick, perhaps more evidence that his Crossword Collaboration efforts are paying off. I’m biased, but I love Saturday and Sunday debuts. Lately I’ve been thinking of how nice it would be to have one more day between Saturday and Sunday to create a three-day weekend, and to have a spot to put really hard daily puzzles. Maybe we could pull something off like this while everyone’s distracted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and Chris Horton
title: Taiwan’s Weapon Against Coronavirus: An Epidemiologist as Vice President
description: Chen Chien-jen has embraced a rare dual role, using his political authority as vice president to criticize China’s response to the virus even as he hunkers down to analyze trends in transmission.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: A Groom, by Proxy, on Zoom
description: Veronica Wickline and Taylor Barker were determined to find a way to wed, even if he couldn’t be there for the ceremony.
content: On Friday, April 17, Veronica Wickline, 26, a part-time Latin teacher and writer, stood at the altar at St. Peter, a Roman Catholic church in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains in Little Washington, Va. Dressed in her wedding dress, veil and pearl earrings, she was there to get married. But the man standing next to her was not her beloved groom. Rather, it was his high school best friend, who was serving as a proxy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hayley Phelan
title: Will Coronavirus Kill Astrology?
description: The pandemic has affected all of us. Who saw it coming?
content: If ever there was one, Susan Miller would be a blue-chip astrologer. So, in January, when she appeared on CBS New York and predicted that 2020 would “be a great year, and it will be a prosperous year,” people listened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: How to Make Your Own Coronavirus Piñata (and Then Smash It)
description: Join the craft renaissance and cope at the same time.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: It was an On-Time Proposal
description: He proposed at the TWA hotel at JFK using the old arrivals departures board from the former midcentury modern terminal.
content: Peter Harrison knew the newly opened TWA hotel at Kennedy Airport in Queens was just the place to propose to Jennifer Markas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edie Thys Morgan
title: Losing My Mom to Alzheimer’s, Then Finding Her Again
description: I wish someone had told me about the beauty that waited at the end of this journey.
content: I lost my mother at about this time last year, after her 10-year struggle with Alzheimer’s disease. During this past year, kind friends have checked in at holidays and birthdays, understandably assuming these first landmark occasions without my mom would be difficult. The truth is something that I was at first ashamed to admit, let alone articulate: Grieving her now, when the loss is complete, feels nothing like I had expected. It feels easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Lewis and Tiffany Hsu
title: The Collateral Damage of the Coronavirus
description: As shopping centers emptied, shows were canceled and office towers turned dark, millions of people suddenly found themselves without jobs.
content: They are ad executives, handymen, servers and wedding D.J.s. They worked in law firms and hotels and retail stores and concert halls. As the outbreak spread, the coronavirus sucked workers from every corner of the American economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Andre Harrell, Executive Who Bridged Hip-Hop and R&B, Dies at 59
description: He founded the influential label Uptown Records and gave a first break to Sean Combs, who would go on to become one of hip-hop’s signature moguls.
content: Andre Harrell, an innovative music executive who in the late 1980s founded Uptown Records, a crucial bridge between the worlds of hip-hop and R&B, and who gave the first career break to Sean Combs, who became one of hip-hop’s signature moguls and global ambassadors, died late Thursday night at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Richard Fausset and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Georgia Killing Puts Spotlight on a Police Force’s Troubled History
description: The shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery has renewed criticism of the police agency that released the two suspects. They were charged by the state months later.
content: BRUNSWICK, Ga. — When the Glynn County Police Department arrived at the scene of a fatal shooting in February in southeastern Georgia, officers encountered a former colleague with the victim’s blood on his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: What Colombia Did With American Spy Tools
description: Under pressure to curb the drug trade, the Colombian army turns to old tricks.
content: Old habits die hard, so there’s something sadly unsurprising in the news that a Colombian army unit used American surveillance equipment, provided to fight Marxist guerrillas and drug traffickers, to spy on journalists, political opponents and public figures. It’s entirely possible that one important goal was to conceal that the fight was dirty and not going particularly well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Hillary Never Married Bill
description: A new novel hypothesizes a different history — and future — for a trailblazing woman.
content: Curtis Sittenfeld likes to imagine the sex lives of presidents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Forces Gulf States to Reckon With Their Scores of Migrant Workers
description: A new cluster of cases in Seoul tests South Korea’s easing. Belarus held a tank parade.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Julian E. Barnes
title: For Flynn, Dropped Charges Are the Latest in a Life Full of Reversals
description: For most of his life, Michael Flynn has swung from being “a good soldier” to an agent of disruption.
content: WASHINGTON — There have always been two sides to Michael T. Flynn. There was the rebellious teenager who surfed during hurricanes and spent a night in juvenile reformatory. Then there was the adult who buckled down, joined the Army and rose to become a three-star general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A Novelist Breaks the Code of Being a Woman in Japan
description: Mieko Kawakami, whose novel “Breasts and Eggs” was just published in English, has become something of a feminist icon in her male-dominated country.
content: TOKYO — To explain the pressure felt by women in Japanese society, the novelist Mieko Kawakami recalls a playground prank from elementary school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: These Are the Things That New Yorkers Achingly Miss
description: The crowds, the big-ticket blockbusters that were a subway ride away, “just everything”: What’s gone has transformed the city.
content: To hop on the train, any train, earbuds intact, alone in the crowd on the way somewhere else. To walk out of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, exhausted as if from a march. The sweet-potato fries and a beer at Tubby Hook Tavern in Inwood; the coffee-cart guy on West 40th Street who remembers you take it black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Will the Coronavirus Crisis Trump the Climate Crisis?
description: The battle over how to spend recovery funds — to quickly restore the old economy or invest in a greener one — will define the post-pandemic world.
content: BRUSSELS — With the global paralysis induced by the coronavirus, levels of pollution and carbon emission are dropping everywhere — leaving bluer skies, visible mountains, splendid wildflowers. Even Venice’s famously murky canals are running clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Breanna Stewart’s Comeback Is Going to Take a Little Longer
description: The 2018 W.N.B.A. most valuable player’s return from a torn Achilles’ tendon was stalled by the coronavirus pandemic. Now she’s just trying to cope with being stuck inside.
content: Along with the rest of the world, athletes have had their careers upended by the coronavirus pandemic. They are giving The New York Times an intimate look at their journeys in periodic installments through the rest of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Virus Forces Persian Gulf States to Reckon With Migrant Labor
description: The Mideast’s wealthiest countries depend on foreigners to do jobs their citizens won’t. But the virus has hobbled the arrangement and drawn attention to its inequities.
content: [Follow our live world updates on the Coronavirus pandemic and outbreak.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Michael Crowley
title: Obama Warns That Dropped Charges Against Flynn Put ‘Rule of Law’ at Risk
description: Speaking to 3,000 supporters, the former president took a sharper line toward the Trump administration than he typically does in public.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President Barack Obama said on Friday that the Justice Department’s decision to drop charges against former national security adviser Michael T. Flynn jeopardized the “rule of law,” adding his voice to the criticism of the extraordinary move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Emily Flitter
title: Elon Musk Lashes Out at Officials Keeping Tesla Plant Closed Over Virus
description: He says he’ll move the headquarters of his electric car company out of California to Texas or Nevada.
content: Elon Musk and local health officials in California clashed on Saturday over the timing of the reopening of Tesla’s factory in Fremont, with the company’s chief executive pushing for an immediate return and the county’s government seeking a delay of about a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba
title: Virus Conspiracists Elevate a New Champion
description: A video showcasing baseless arguments by Dr. Judy Mikovits, including attacks on Dr. Anthony Fauci, has been viewed more than eight million times in the past week.
content: In a video posted to YouTube on Monday, a woman animatedly described an unsubstantiated secret plot by global elites like Bill Gates and Dr. Anthony Fauci to use the coronavirus pandemic to profit and grab political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Andrés Iniesta Plots a Return to Barcelona, Where the Beauty Is Gone
description: Iniesta turned from aspiring schoolboy to soccer icon on a Barcelona team that captivated the world. Now in Japan, he hopes for a return to a club plagued by infighting.
content: From 6,500 miles away, Andrés Iniesta has been contemplating his return. He doesn’t know when it will be, or under what circumstances, but he is sure he wants to go back to F.C. Barcelona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: There’s Money Stuck in Your Dependent Care Account. Now What?
description: After-school programs are closed. Day care centers are shut down. Summer camp might not happen. If you’re stuck with money you can’t use, you’ll lose it — and pay taxes on it.
content: You did everything right. You read the email from human resources and signed up for a dependent care account. Your employer siphons pretax money from your paycheck, and you’ll get a little back upon request after paying each day care bill, or in a lump sum after covering summer camp costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: A Drug Cocktail Hastens Recovery in Some Coronavirus Patients
description: A combination of three antiviral drugs, including interferon, seemed to speed recovery, researchers reported.
content: Patients with mild to moderate Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus, appeared to improve more quickly if they were treated with a three-drug cocktail, compared with a group receiving just a two-drug combination, scientists reported on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Divorcing Parents Have a Right to Post Their Stories Online, Court Says
description: A ruling in Massachusetts finds that involuntary nondisparagement orders, commonly used to keep spouses from discussing their cases on social media, are unconstitutional.
content: The acrimonious split of Masha and Ronnie Shak ended up where many divorces do these days — on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Border Crossings
description: Adam Fromm’s Sunday puzzle gets through customs.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Everyone here loves to find the theme, and there’s something special about a theme that exposes something hidden in plain sight. Today we have an example of this phenomenon that takes “I can’t believe nobody ever noticed this before!” to the nth degree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: How to Have a Picnic, Safely
description: The winter chill is lifting. So are some of the strictest stay-at-home orders. Here are strategies to dine outside while still protecting yourself and those around you.
content: It’s hard to believe that it’s already May and that we’re approaching several months of sunny, sweater-less weather. Like flower petals, some states are slowly opening, too, including many once-closed parks, which means it’ll be hard to resist the urge to picnic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe DePaolo
title: Why America Loves U.F.C., the First Sport to Return
description: In an age of trolls, economic insecurity and social isolation, mixed martial arts gives fans a rush of harsh reality.
content: It comes as no surprise to its ardent followers that the Ultimate Fighting Championship, known as U.F.C., will be the first organization to stage a major professional sports event in the United States since the spread of Covid-19 induced a monthslong live sports hiatus. Its brash president, Dana White, never wanted to cease operations in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: ‘Nerve-Racking and Very Unusual’: Snow in May Worries Growers
description: The coronavirus pandemic was already making life on the farm unpredictable, and then came an Arctic blast.
content: Across New York and New England, farmers and growers watched with worry on Saturday morning as a late season blast of Arctic air and even snow descended on fragile fruits and vegetables that had just begun to poke through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Glover Blackwell and Darrick Hamilton
title: Will We Face Depression-Era Job Losses? Let’s Not Find Out
description: Congress should enact a federal jobs guarantee.
content: On Friday, the Labor Department announced that over 20.5 million Americans lost their jobs in April, bringing the unemployment rate to 14.7 percent. This level of devastation has not been reached since the Great Depression. With more than one in four companies shuttered to minimize the pandemic’s death toll and at least 30 million workers seeking unemployment benefits, we are in the throes of an unprecedented jobs crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Live and Let Die, Trump-Style
description: The world’s greatest con artist has finally come up against a foe he can’t fool.
content: WASHINGTON — This is not a good time for vampires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: My Son Is a Nurse. I Worry Every Day About Losing Him to the Coronavirus.
description: His New York City hospital has been all pandemic, all the time.
content: HOUSTON — “Can you hear that?” my son, Sam, asked me a month or so ago, interrupting our conversation to hold his phone up to his open car window. “It’s for essential workers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Roy Horn, Who Dazzled Audiences as Half of Siegfried & Roy, Dies at 75
description: He and his partner mesmerized crowds for decades, using a stunning mix of magic, costumes and exotic animals. He died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Nightly Applause Is Nice, but Some Doctors Think Votes Would Be Nicer
description: “My day job is talking people into getting colonoscopies,” one doctor said. So how much harder could the campaign trail be?
content: Maxine Dexter, an intensive care physician, remembers exactly where she was sitting the Thursday morning her political ambitions were born. She was looking out her bedroom window toward northwest Portland — the snow-capped peak of Mount Adams winking at her from across the valley. She clutched a coffee her husband had brought upstairs in her favorite mug, the one that read: “Well yes, I’m overqualified.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: As Job Losses Mount, Lawmakers Face a Make-or-Break Moment
description: The United States just lost 20 million jobs. The wrong federal response could make those layoffs a permanent fixture of the U.S. economy and sentence thousands of companies to bankruptcy.
content: WASHINGTON — As the nation confronts unemployment levels not seen since the Great Depression, Congress and the Trump administration face a pivotal choice: Continue spending trillions trying to shore up businesses and workers, or bet that state reopenings will jump-start the United States economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A ‘Big Fat Greek Wedding’ Will Have to Wait
description: Vungelia Glyptis and John Damianos, both from Greek families and graduates of Dartmouth, were forced to considerably scale down their wedding plans.
content: When John Damianos’s cellphone began buzzing on the Dartmouth campus in September 2015, he realized he was being FaceTimed by Vungelia Glyptis, a fellow student whom he had not talked to in two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: A New Lease With More Space Than They Needed
description: They were roommates, then friends, then had a first date just a few days before they planned to become roommates again.
content: Renata Certo-Ware and Tristan Graham, both 34, met in 2016, when she and her roommates at the time posted on Craigslist about an extra bedroom in their Philadelphia apartment for sublet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Many Ways Moms Grow
description: Motherhood is all about changing. Continually. Sometimes as a parent, many times as a person. Since no two moms are alike in their transformations, we asked 16 of them to share their stories.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Weiner
title: Little Richard, Flamboyant Wild Man of Rock ’n’ Roll, Dies at 87
description: Delving deeply into the wellsprings of gospel music and the blues, and screaming as if for his very life, he created something new, thrilling and dangerous.
content: Richard Penniman, better known as Little Richard, who combined the sacred shouts of the black church and the profane sounds of the blues to create some of the world’s first and most influential rock ’n’ roll records, died on Saturday morning in Tullahoma, Tenn. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Weiner
title: Little Richard, Flamboyant Wild Man of Rock ’n’ Roll, Dies at 87
description: Delving deeply into the wellsprings of gospel music and the blues, and screaming as if for his very life, he created something new, thrilling and dangerous.
content: Richard Penniman, better known as Little Richard, who combined the sacred shouts of the black church and the profane sounds of the blues to create some of the world’s first and most influential rock ’n’ roll records, died on Saturday morning in Tullahoma, Tenn. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs and Edgar Sandoval
title: Mysterious Coronavirus Illness Claims 3 Children in New York
description: A baffling ailment linked to Covid-19 has killed three young children and sickened 73 others across the state.
content: A mysterious syndrome has killed three young children in New York and sickened 73 others, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Saturday, an alarming rise in a phenomenon that was first publicly identified earlier this week.
source.name: The New York Times
